OK, fixed to centralize the logic to `IndexOpsMixin`. Even though `update_inplace` is defined in both `IndexOpsMixin` and `Index`, it will never called in `drop_duplicates` case (`Index.drop_duplicates` blocks `inplace` kw, and it is better for proper `docstring`)
ok with changing to this, though using `(~values).astype(bool)` is quite common in the code base - if someone wanted to clean up this would be appreciated

@shoyer @jreback I improved the checking here according to your recommendations - in the case of `Series` it's the same logic as before and in the case of `Index` it uses the `inferred_type` attribute

I don't think you can accept `mixed-integer`, as these are in general python integer objects which need stringification first (which we _could_ do, but that's a separate issue).

```
In [10]: pd.lib.infer_dtype([1,2,'a'])
Out[10]: 'mixed-integer'
```

@jreback It is to be compat with current `Series` behavior. In above case, `Series.str` is applied to all the elements and leave non-str as `NaN`.

```
s = pd.Series([1, 2, 'a'])
s.str.len()
# 0   NaN
# 1   NaN
# 2     1
# dtype: float64
```

Added. If I understood you correctly what you are asking for.

Maybe the issue is here. Because DataFrame wants Python types, we have to convert from numpy to Python types. Before, this was done inside C (inside tolist call), now it is done in Python.

So in some way, this might require numpy to have an iterator reading out Python values, implemented in C, to make this same efficiency.

I would say that even leaving aside language differences, we are now making ``len(self._values)`` separate calls rather than a single one. We know numpy indexing has overhead, and I think this is perfectly acceptable.

**EDIT** I was missing the point, see my [last comment](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/20796#issuecomment-407388461).

Yeah, [here's](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/commit/2773e3473cbf0a6cc875dc7c065172b7656f1f53) your commit.
Oh, I know. `item` wants an index of the item you want to get back.

comments.body:
Note that the *default* behavior right now is the same as `dtype="datetime64[ns]"`, i.e. the timezone info is lost. I don't think that's what we want, but I'm waiting on #24024 to be done before making that change.

I also have a branch (https://github.com/TomAugspurger/pandas/pull/new/dt-array-3) that's deprecating the behavior for Series.__array__ and Index.__array__ returning datetime64[ns] for tz-aware values. That's currently blocked by #24024.

comments.body: technically this could cause a copy, right? so should we set copy=False if ``dtype`` is not None?

Correct, we may be double copying. I'm not quite sure how to detect that. I'm not sure how to best handle this.

One option I considered is adding a method to the EA interface `_to_numpy` that returns `(ndarray, did_copy)`. Then this could be written as

```python
if is_extension_array_dtype(self.dtype):
    result, copied = self.array._to_numpy(dtype, copy)

if copy and not copied:
    return result
```

Do you think avoiding the double-copy is worth that complexity? Or perhaps there's a cleaner way I haven't thought of.
no ok for now, though maybe add a comment. note that @jbrockmendel basically does this in the in various parts of the datetimelike constructors.

I don't work super much with datetime arrays, but ``if self.dtype.kind in ["m", "M"]:`` looks very implicit, while the old way was more readable. Would it be possible to do e.g. ``if needs_i8_conversion(self.dtype)`` instead?

the equivalent alternative would be `is_timedelta64_dtype(self._values.dtype) or is_datetime64_dtype(self._values.dtype)`.  I prefer the `dtype.kind` lookup because it is significantly more performant, but either way works
This is not my area so much, so ok to this from me.
why do you think you need the if condition that was added?

`collections.abc.Mapping` does not declare nor implement `__missing__`, that is a concept of `dict`. In case you use a subclass of `collections.abc.Mapping` which isn't a subclass of `dict`, you cannot rely on `__missing__`.
You can see an example on the second test I added, `test_map_abc_mapping_with_missing`.
I think can just simplify to `isinstance(mapper, dict)` then no? Check for __missing__ after that is duplicative?

No, since `dict` doesn't have a `__missing__` method on its own.
In `dict.__getitem__`'s implementation there is a reference to `__missing__` in case the object is a subclass of `dict` and implements it, but `dict` itself does not implement `__missing__`.
I suggest reading [dict's documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#dict), specifically the `__getitem__` part noted as `d[key]` for explanation.
Was adding this condition discussed somewhere? I would have thought just keep existing behaviour
This is the bugfix part.  dt64, dt64tz, and td64 we're currently incorrectly returning int

^ current behavior
Yes, I think we should keep the behaviour of `item` to return a python scalar (where possible of course, so for datetime/timedelta it is fine to return a pandas Timestamp/Timedelta I think)
